summary: Alfred Kralik (James Stewart) and Klara Novak (Margaret Sullavan) are employees at Matuschek and Company, a general store in Budapest. Klara and Alfred are constantly at odds with each other, butting heads and disagreeing on almost everything. Both are enamored of their respective pen pals, who serve as welcome distractions in their lives. Little do they know, they are each the other's pen pal and, despite outward differences, have unwittingly fallen in love through their letters.

reviews.content: An very entertaining movie , would be worth a watch

Two people fall in love without even knowing each other in The Shop Around the Corner. While the film had decent acting by James Stewart and Frank Morgan, the film was dragged by Margaret Sullavan's wooden acting abilities. Despite the film's writing by Samson Raphaelson was clever, the film wasn't really funny. The Shop Around the Corner may be a pleasant film to those who are very fond of the romantic-comedy genre but for anyone else, it's just your average film about anonymous romance during the holiday season.

"Didn't he impress you as being rather witty?"
"Well he struck me as rather depressed." 
Jimmy Stewart throwing a punch at a solid 75% of film reviewers. 

A cute and charming script that was among the first to really take advantage of a pair of leads that could level snide remarks just as well as they could make doe eyes at one another. Despite the inherent humor and sweetness in the premise of two people that are falling for one another without realizing it, The Shop Around the Corner touches on surprisingly dark territory - infidelity, grief, and suicide, to name a few - all while dedicating a surprising proportion of its runtime to the operation of the titular shop. And yet, it strangely works, benefiting from the added characterization, the authenticity imparted from the daily bickering, and the eventual triumph of happy sentiments over the persistent conflict and chaos of daily life at Matuschek and Company. I'm not sure I personally enjoyed it quite as much as films with a similar frenemies dynamic of the period (particularly It Happened One Night), but it is still very solid and worthy of a watch mostly for the great back and forth between Sullavan and Stewart, perhaps slightly less so for the Capra-esque/Dickensian subplots. (3.5/5)
The comic script is sharp for its age. Warm hearted, fun comedy with Hames oh shucks Stewart playing the Everyman again.
Jimmy Stewart is his usual wonderful self in this delightful romantic comedy.
Predictable at every point, but nonetheless a charming tale of love, community and trust.

The atmosphere alone wins me over: classic Hollywood soundstages lit gorgeously and photographed to perfection. But the central relationship between Klara and Alfred is a bit lackluster, something You've Got Mail would later get right. There's not enough budding romance before Klara suddenly reveals she had a thing for Alfred the whole time; she never showed a hint of it. She's not lovable either, so it's not a good look for a figure like Jimmy Stewart to throw himself at an uninterested woman. Despite this, supporting characters create a wonderful, vibrant energy, and there's so much funny wit that's well performed that even a problem as central as the key relationship is forgivable.

I've seen the musical version of Ernst Lubitsch's black-and-white classic (‘She Loves Me') and of course the rom-com remake (‘You've Got Mail') but it is only now that I get the chance to be cinematically educated with the original and despite its often corny and antiquated attitudes, there's just no denying the gentle yet glorious innocence and charm this film is bursting with and its ability to melt the meanest and hardest of hearts especially during this festive season. Effortlessly directed by Lubitsch, it's set in Budapest (where all signs are in Hungarian but everyone's speaking in English of course) as a result of its source material (a play by Miklos Laszlo), and revolves around the employees of Matuschek & Co., the titular shop around the corner. Interestingly, I find the father-and-son-esque relationship between the owner, the wonderful Frank Morgan's Hugo Matuschek and his longest serving employee, Alfred Kralik, played by a very young James Stewart (who then only takes second billing) more compelling than the romantic subplot between Kralik and Margaret Sullavan's Klara, who unbeknown to each other were secret pen-pals before they became bickering co-workers. What surprise me most is how much the rom-com was amplified in the 1998 remake compared to the original; while a passing reference to ungentlemanly behaviour in the stock room sadly still rings as true today as it did 80 years ago. If some of the comedy feels a little dated, the alluringly witty dialogue can still manage to liven things up. In this strange and bothersome year, this Christmas classic is perhaps the exact escapist tonic we all need to bring a little joy and Christmas cheer to our lives, even if it is over-idealistic poppycock.

A bow-legged rom-com with a remarkable amount of emotional range, like Jimmy Stewart's other Christmas classic, Lubitsch does not simply gloss over the negativity of the nativity season that so many of us experience—the arguments, the anxiety, the commercialism. Rather, the film understands that the joy of the holiday is precarious, as easily overwhelmed by the bitter and darker feelings these days bring with them as the potential cheer can be deepened by recognizing and not repressing such despair.

The strength of The Shop Around the Corner is in the cast and the characters they create. The gift shop is full of a unique group of employees that each have fun mannerisms and personalities that make it feel like a charming place I’d like to visit. I couldn’t figure out why the film took place in Budapest, since almost everyone in it is American and it never feels like they are in Hungary, but that is an unimportant detail that they mentioned at the beginning and I quickly forgot about. I found the mystery of the film to be quite interesting, so I had fun trying to figure out why Mr. Matuschek was angry with Kralik. You could sense the history in their relationship, and it made me instantly curious what made it break down. When we discover the truth, it then seemed somewhat obvious what was really going on, but they avoid revealing everything long enough for me to puzzle through the questions that the story was raising. However, since that was the aspect of the film I latched onto, it didn’t feel all that comedic. This part of the film is a relatively dark story, and even when good things happen it’s in the wake of some depressing details. What I think they want you to focus on is the love story, which I knew about before watching. I think The Shop Around the Corner suffered from the fact that I have seen You’ve Got Mail many times before and that film took the concept of this romance and made it work much better. In comparison, this romance felt almost like an afterthought. Many of the times the letters were mentioned it was in passing while a number of much more important stories were going on. I also didn’t feel like there was a strong animosity between the two leads, which is necessary to pull off the story they are trying to tell. However, it was nice to see some of the scenes that You’ve Got Mail copied from this one. It triggered some fond memories and made me want to watch that movie again soon. I feel like I’m being a bit harsh when I write about The Shop Around the Corner, but I think it’s the comparison that hurt it. If I watched this movie in a vacuum prior to ever seeing the remake, then I think it would have charmed me a lot. It’s a nice film that I found pleasant to watch, and one I’ll probably seek out again someday.

A film with many layers and a joy to watch, itâ(TM)s a real triumph for director Ernst Lubitsch.  He gives us a romantic comedy in which the romance is just a part of a larger canvas, one that touches us in so many ways: the loneliness of the holiday season, the humiliation of betrayal, needing to endure other people and the boss at oneâ(TM)s workplace to support a family, and of course, an unlikely love that only comes from scratching beneath the surface.  

Lubitsch is so complete in the way he tells this story, and yet seems to tread lightly as he does so.  He fleshes out his characters in the simplest of ways, with little gestures and comments.  He exercises the deftness of restraint in all things, from the slyness of his comedy to letting silence and his actorsâ(TM) faces say it all when appropriate.  He gives us a rich symphony of human emotions, showing us human dignity and the angels of our better natures, but also our pettiness, jealousy, vanity, and disdain.  In love, he shows us the importance of inner character but also acknowledges physical appeal.  In community, he gives us a sense of comradeship, but also the inevitable pecking order and little rivalries.  There is real wisdom in his observations of how people behave, but also a philosophical acceptance and elegant refinement in how he presents it.  He always seems to thread the needle, and maybe thatâ(TM)s the essence of what the â~Lubitsch touchâ(TM) is all about.

One theme in the film is how people communicate, and the need to be honest and yet graceful.  We see this in how one salesman (Jimmy Stewart) talks to the boss (Frank Morgan) contrasted to the way another does (Joseph Schildkraut), a guy who sucks up and is an example of grace without truth.  We also see it in how Stewart and the new saleswoman (Margaret Sullavan) antagonize each another, never giving one another the benefit of the doubt, and often being forthright but lacking grace.  They are of course much more eloquent and kind to one another as anonymous pen-pals, and it shows us how much our openness and attitude towards someone else shapes our view of them.

The cast is fantastic, led by excellent performances from Morgan and Stewart.  Felix Bressart as the family man and William Tracy as the errand boy stand out in supporting roles.  I wasnâ(TM)t as wild about Margaret Sullavan, but she fits the part quite well.  The scene she has with Stewart in the cafÃ (C) is wonderfully acerbic, and is preceded by Bressart pointing out just who has the copy of Anna Karenina with the red carnation in a clever way.  Another great scene is Stewartâ(TM)s dismissal, which is one he and Lubitsch both execute as true masters.  I also loved that moment Frank Morgan has with the new errand boy after seeking someone to go to dinner with.  

There is such a genuine feeling to this film, where Lubitsch really takes us into the world of this little shop.  As in life, there is despair, humiliation, and bickering, just as there is warmth, friendship, and higher love.  This is an old film to seek out.

Just happen to stumble upon this picture during this Christmas Holiday (2018), and without a doubt the interplay between Sullavan and Stewart is superb and beyond comparison. And the story line is great! Can't think of any other romantic movie, direction, story line or acting as good!

A great story built on well fleshed out characters. It is a great romantic comedy that doesn't shy away from home flaws. If you want a movie with substance and humor, this is for you. I watch it every Christmas, as a great deal of the story happens around the holiday season.

One of my three favorite movies. Made in a time when audiences didn't have to be beaten over the head to get the plot but could appreciate the nuances that are all through this film. Cute and enjoyable!
Just a great movie. Old time class and great acting with a special ploy.

You can see the building blocks for all subsequent romance films being set here: quirky side characters, contentious love interests, frustrating misunderstandings. What sets it apart from its slew of disposable descendants is how Lubitsch keeps his world perfectly contained; 90% stays around the wonderful staff of this small shop. Like Stewart's other Xmas film "Wonderful Life", TSAtC naturally mixes drama and humor right up against each other. Often funny, often heartbreaking, and always romantic.

A film where you really need to be able to follow the dialog and who is speaking to who and what. The other thing is the body language with the micro expressions on the actors faces. I think that this is one of the better acting films. 

I saw this a second time and the story made much more sense because I knew what to look for in the other character while the other was saying the dialog. 

What I find interesting is how a key figure to this story is in an affair with one of the characters in the film that is never seen but only referred to by other characters or on the phone. Not much is seen from that particular character as a sign of a relationship but just small hints. 

I think the costumes stand out in this film. It is obvious to me that each costume choice perfectly fits the character they are portraying. 

I think one of the major stand out characters in this film was Pepi Katona. I like Mr. Pepi Katona in his lines and way he speaks. Pepi almost stole the film by his performance even though we see so little of his character in the film. His character changed drastically when he went from errand messenger to a clerk. I even liked how Pepi's voice and tone changed on the phone as he talked to different characters. Even Pepi's clothes and how he presented himself to others changes in this film as we presents himself to others as different characters. 

I liked the scene where Pirovitch is looking through the window of the cafÃ (C) to see who is the girl to Alfred. I enjoy the scene because in it we never see the girl. The scene is purely driven by dialog and what the listeners reactions are to the speaker yet we understand or get a mental picture of what the other sees. Because we don't see the girl and we only can infer what is happening and going on based upon the dialog and reactions. 

I like Jimmy Stewarts acting in this film. Just by his body language, facial language he is able to convey a lot in this film about what he really is thinking without necessarily saying anything.


I also like the loyalty and character of Pirovitch.

What gets me about this film is how it mostly takes place at the shop but never felt bird staying in one location. This film is mostly driven by the performances.

Pretty fun romantic comedy back in the Golden Age of Hollywood starring Jimmy Stewart, Margaret Sullivan, and Frank "The Wizard of Oz" Morgan. To some it's considered a staple of the Christmas season. While it's by no means a true Christmas film, The Shop Around the Corner has a very entertaining cast filled with great acting all around (including Jimmy Stewart, one of my all-time favorites) and the comedy is fairly good for a romantic comedy that would have been extremely cheesy and syrupy had it been made today by the Hallmark Channel. Delightful, charming, sweet and genuinely funny, it's set in a chocolate box world when shops were all quaint boutiques with names like Matuschek and Sons on the door, people wrote real letters, $2 could buy you a suitcase and everyone knew one another on the street. It has dark twists but crucially everything works out for the best. Probably just as exciting as the finale for me was Mr Matuschek not having to spend Christmas alone! Such a sweet moment. 

It's A Wonderful Life is my favourite movie of all time, Mr Smith Goes To Washington got a 5 star review from me too, which leads me to ask...did Jimmy Stewart ever make a bad movie? Based on the movies I've seen so far, he has to be one of my favourite actors of all time. This was a great one for the holidays.

A Hungarian clerk falls in love with a pen pal who turns out to be his co-worker, with whom he has an antagonistic relationship.
A remarkably dark romantic comedy, The Shop Around the Corner falls well short of charming (any claim it has to that adjective comes in the person of the naturally delightful Jimmy Stewart). Instead subplots of infidelity and a failing business cloud whatever romantic juice can be squeezed out of the primary plotline.  The film is not boring nor are the characters bland, but the heavy air of the Hungarian milieu and the heavier subplots bring the story to a slow climb toward nothing interesting.
Overall, I suspect the modern You've Got Mail might have a better tone but less substance, and as a whole, this story feels too uneven.

Much like the films of old, what makes this movie so charming is the banter. I loved how they kept it all pretty G back in the days; no unnecessary swearing or violence or nudity, but still managed to make a pretty entertaining story.  I prefer this version to the Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan remake "You've Got Mail.". This movie was fairly simple and straight-forward, no unnecessary characters or sub-plots but it was a little corny and naïve, but that's a reflection of the times. I love Jimmy Stewart (who plays Alfred Kralik), he's so adorable and he has good chemistry with Margaret Sullavan (Klara Novak). But I think my favorite in the film was Felix Bressart, who plays Pirovitch and is essentially Kralik's conscience and guiding light. He was Dave Chappelle without the snarkiness. This film was really and thoroughly enjoyable.

Jimmy Stewart wins this thing hands down (even though I am a huge Hanks fan) but the whole movie doesn't stand against the 1998 you've got a mail for me atleast !

Winsomely ironic and surprisingly modern humor shines all throughout Ernst Lubitsch's "The Shop Around The Corner;" A brilliantly uplifting romantic comedy with two lovable lead performances.
Delightful romantic comedy drama about the relationships between employees inside a small gift store, often entertaining, while also sobering  and uplifting.

Being a fan of You've Got Mail for so long, it was only a matter of time before I checked out the original which the former was loosely based on. Sans the internet and anti-big corporation sentiments, this film focuses more on the relationship between the two romantic antagonists. Even though I love the witty and often amusing exchanges between Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks' characters in YGM, the relationship that evolved in TSATC seemed more plausible and natural. The romanticism of communicating through the written word is also more evident here. There's something to be said about penning your thoughts on paper as the receiver eagerly awaits to find the envelope sitting in their mailbox, as opposed to AOL's exclamation over your PC speaker. Also, I will take Jimmy Stewart over Tom Hanks any day.

While this wouldn't quite make it as one of my favorite Jimmy Stewart movies, it's still a classic well worth seeing. It's an original and clever romantic story, which later inspired the movie You've Got Mail (which I still haven't seen, somehow). It's not as much of a comedy as I went in thinking it would be, but it still works really well as a more straightforward romance. It's also got a great group of side characters, the sort you never really get in movies these days.

The story, which is set in Budapest - most probably only because the original stage play was Hungarian - follows two clerks working together in a shop: Alfred (Stewart), a longtime salesman, and Klara (Margaret Sullavan), the new hire. By day, they disagree about things and snipe at each other, but at night they each go home and engage in passionate romances-by-mail. What neither realizes is that the love letters they've been writing have in fact been written to each other. You can imagine how the movie goes from there.

Jimmy Stewart is, well, Jimmy Stewart here, as he is in every movie; but he's perhaps a little less Jimmy Stewart-y than usual. The character isn't quite rounded out with the same "aw shucks" likability I usually associate with Stewart; we almost never see him except at work, and I actually found his behavior towards the end of the movie almost a little cruel. I realize the movie's over as soon as the secret is out, but I felt like it would have been more fun to watch them deal in greater depth with the revelation, rather than having the revelation instantly solve everything. Margaret Sullavan is terrific as Klara; it's really something to watch her not know the secret when we in the audience do. The supporting players are strong too, especially Frank Morgan as the gruff but well-meaning shop owner Mr. Matuschek.

The movie was directed by Ernst Lubitsch, a German emigre who became quite well-respected in Hollywood. Somehow this was the first movie I've seen by Lubitsch. As was the case with many great classical Hollywood directors, there's no obvious personal style, and yet the film is immaculately directed. Those old-timers were real professionals. Like I said, I expected the film to have more humor, and I was a little baffled by some of the Stewart character's behavior late in the film. But overall it's still quite a fine movie.

Ernst Lubistch is a canonized name whose filmography has kept evading me until now, THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER, acclaimed as one of his most competent and most mature light comedies, is the ultimatum delight to savor under any circumstances. 

One might fully aware that this film is the archetype of  Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan's commercial sensation YOU'VE GOT MAIL (1998, 7/10), but even its inception is over half a century older than the latter, the former still manage to overshadow it (or even any other praiseworthy rom-coms) in every possible aspect. An ingenious script renders a witty plot set-up which only leaves our leading lady unwittingly snared inside a white lie while audiences' appetite has been fully whetted and the final revelation is well-anticipated, humorous, affecting and sincerely good-natured, this is "the" kind of film which Hollywood doesn't (or is unable to) produce any more, pitifully!

The temperaments of the two leads are plain congenial and mutually harmonious, the James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan pair oozes the optimal chemistry in the conventional rom-com mis-matched setting. The two represents the quintessential precious nature of the two sexes, role models of the golden age and rarely can be found in reality now, it all reminds us nostalgically what a pure golden-heart could be and elicits more whole-hearted appreciation. Stewart would win his Oscar for THE PHILADELPHIA STORY (1940, 8/10) the same year, but under Lubistch's guidance, his slightly reserved suaveness and gentleman-like diffidence achieve an irresistible personal debonair which also is difficult to find at present. Sullavan, not quite a household name but in this film, her performance is exquisite, heartwarming, say, the ending, when she finally gets to know the man of her dream is her bickering partner in the shop, her psychologically-shocking-but-exhilaratingly-content transition is the killing of the film and saves the film from being an emotional overkill or worse, a stroke of bathos. 

Frank Morgan (afresh from THE WIZARD OF OZ 1939, 8/10) and Joseph Schildkraut both deliver excellent work as the credulous but kind-hearted shop owner and the sycophantic poseur in the shop respectively, pristine frills added to the main storyline. 

 THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER, is a rare gem of its own kind, I highly doubt Lubitsch could excel himself in his canon, where I will burrow and wish me luck!

Starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan with direction by Ernst Lubitsch, the film follows the events in a little shop in Budapest Hungary. Alfred Kralik (Stewart) is the most respected employee in the shop and when Ms. Novak (Sullivan) comes in he advises her no jobs are open. However, she does land one and thus begins their rocky relationship. They are constantly at each others throats arguing. Both of them want to end the conflict on a good note as they go their separate ways to marry people that they were corresponding with by letter. When Stewart is to finally meet his unknown lover, he is shocked to look in and see Ms. Novak. Through a series of events she finally figures out he was the writer of all her letters and the two former enemies fall in love. This unorthodox romance has good characters and comedic moments that make it enjoyable to watch.
Sharp, charming script, and Jimmy Stewart makes me weak in the knees.

This is movie is where we get today's version of You've Got Mail. But The Shop Around The Corner did it better. I love this movie and suggest that anybody who has seen the newer version to watch this film. It's playfully funny, and very charming.
A heartwarming tale full of wit, truth, plot twists, great acting, and wonderful romance.
Sort of Christmassy classic with Jimmy Stewart.  It's no 'Wonderful Life' but it has some nice script gags and a neat romantic conclusion, goes a bit around the block to finally get there though.
Great movie; one of my favorite James Stewart films,

I just watched the movie and it's such a darling. It was humorous yet romantic and the chemistry between Stewart and Sullavan worked it. Other than that, James Stewart looked so dashing. Two thumbs up, hands down and kudos to this movie. The Shop around the corner is a movie that you would love to watch over and over again!

Only wish movies were still made with this quality of screenplay, good humor, and quality acting. The modern You've Got Mail movie is based on it, and is a tepid version of this great comedy. We truly have lost a great deal in the modern movie age.

So sweet and well done. The story flows so nicely. The characters are very likable. Such a sweet little movie for a romantic date! Just like "You've got Mail" I was really into this..really good classic that you defiantly can't get enough of!

With a subtle melancholic overtone, The Shop Around the Corner amuses with its perfectly enchanting and fetching atmosphere. It's a different kind of a love story, one that seems fresh and up-to-date even nowadays. A man and a woman work at the same gift-shop, arguing and fighting all the time. However, unknowingly, they're quickly falling in love with each other through the post. As laughable as it might sound, they're sending each other love letters through their pen-pal connection and, at the same time, assaulting each other verbally every day in the real-life. It's a romantic comedy of mistakes and hidden feelings, enhanced by the fantastic supporting cast, which adds a few engaging subplots to the whole. It's got this totally adorable feel, that will later be repeated in another marvelous comedies with James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan in the lead. A classic in its genre.
it was good, but really slow.

YOU'VE GOT EMAIL is said to be a remake of this movie but there are many differences. To say the former is inspired by this classic is more like it. 

It is a sweet love comedy and the lines can be so wickedly funny. And I thought there will be a generation gap. I am rather surprised that the love story doesn't hog the limelight. There are also subplots revolve around the harmonious working relationships at the shop. 

It doesn't strike me as a memorable movie but I like its heartwarming humanity. It is a perfect movie to watch late at night and then go to bed with a smile. 

Rating: B
